http://www.politico.eu/article/why-france-is-so-lukewarm-on-lagarde/ It does seem as if "unless new details about the Tapie case make her appointment impossible, Lagarde will sail through to a second term." Nevertheless, it also seems the evidence is already in-hand to find her guilty of at least two negligence charges. Negligence is, in short, failure to perform a duty incumbent in a role. When Lagarde says she "acted on orders from then-President Nicolas Sarkozy," she acknowledges the surrender of her role authority to Sarkozy. It's the old (invalid) Nuremberg defense. She then pleads lack of knowledge (i.e., "hinting in previous depositions that she had not been fully briefed on the matter by her chief of staff at the time, Stéphane Richard, now chairman and chief executive of French telecom group Orange"). It's incumbent in the role to know what you need to know prior to undertaking a decision. Two counts of negligence plain as day. Richard has apparently refused to disclose what he did in fact communicate to Lagarde, although it seems there are reams of documentary evidence that might make him change his mind. In any case, I am a little surprised that would-be "risk averse" banker-types would load such reputational risk upon the IMF. I won't go so far as to suggest the trial is a potential bargaining chip with Lagarde, for she seemed sufficiently pliant enough without such additional inducement.

As others have pointed out (@Anneinak, @einsteinjs, etc.), a significant number of major IMF shareholders have already come out in support of Lagarde’s nomination, which was announced on Friday. By my back of the napkin math, countries holding 46.8% of the total votes in the IMF have already publically indicated support for Lagarde’s candidacy. Countries indicating support for Lagarde are also represented on the IMF’s Executive Board by 9 Executive Directors, and these 9 Executive Director’s control 56.86% of the vote. As a result, it seems all but certain that Lagarde will be appointed to a second term.  Background:  The Managing Director of the IMF is selected by the IMF’s Executive Board, which consists of 24 Executive Directors (who each represent a country or a group of countries). Each Executive Director’s vote is weighted based on the contributions of the country or group of countries they represent. Base case: In October 2015, Christine Lagarde (CL) announced her willingness to continue as Managing Director (MD) of the International Monetary Fund (IMF), saying: “I’m prepared to serve, but it’s not my call.” (1)
On 22/01/2015 she confirmed this, saying: "Yes, I am running for a second mandate," and “I've had the honour of receiving support since the opening of the procedure,”. (2) As she is still available for the job, the analysis should concentrate on her likeliness to be elected: As of 21/01/2016 the nomination process for her successor is open and will close on 11/02/2016. The board has announced that it will aim to find the next MD by 03/03/2016, leaving ample time before the end of CL’s term on 05/07/2016. (3) Immediately on 21/01/2016, CL was officially nominated by the UK chancellor of the exchequer, George Osborne and on the same day received backing from Germany and France (French prime minister Manuel Valls said that the finance ministry would issue an official statement on 22/01/2016). (1) She also received backing from China, whose board representative, Jin Zhongxia, said: “We also support her to serve a second term,” and “Christine Lagarde has demonstrated outstanding leadership and strategic vision, as well as excellent professionalism and coordination skills,” (4) Under CL’s leadership, the IMF has added the Renminbi to the IMF SDR currency basket, after a prolonged campaign by the People’s Republic. (1) (5) All of these countries appoint an exclusive director to the board of directors and on their own make up 18.20% of the votes. (6) In their selection process guidelines, the IMF specifies that the MD is appointed by a majority of the votes, while noting that the objective is an appointment by consensus. (7) In addition, US vice-president Joe Biden has also indicated support and was backed up by treasury secretary Jack Lew. (1) US support would put CL at 34.90% of votes. (6) However, the country refrained from a formal backing. (8) CL noted on 22/01/2015 that the US usually waits until the end of the nomination process before backing a specific candidate but also emphasized the support she had received from Biden and Lew. (2) While they do not appoint an exclusive board member, the following countries have also issued statements of support for CL:  Mexico - the country is this time not backing Agustín Carstens, its central bank governor, who is not in the running for this term. (9)
The Netherlands - finance minister, Jeroen Dijsselbloem, confirmed the country’s support via Twitter. (8)
Spain - Reuters reports that an official source in the economy ministry announced support for CL. (9) (10)
Finland - at the WEF, finance minister Alexander Stubb announced that CL had the country’s support. (9)
Korea - in a television interview CL listed the country as a supporter of hers. (11) While these countries do not have an exclusive representative, they make up a substantial share in their respective groups: (6) Spain and Mexico have 63.14% of the voting power in the Latin America group, while the groups representative is also a Spanish economist. I will assume that the LA group will vote for CL with a probability of 80%. Finland only has a share of 15.62% in the Nordics group. The representative of the group is Norwegian. Assume conservative 45% probability of the executive voting for CL. The Netherlands have 31.63% of the votes in the Eastern European group. The group’s representative is Dutch. Assume 60% probability of group voting for CL. Korea has 37.67% of the APAC group’s votes. I will hence assume that the group votes for CL with a probability of 50%. During her term, CL has developed good relations with international leaders, DM and EM countries alike, mitigating the risk factor of opposition from non-core countries. During her tenure more voting power was shifted towards emerging markets. I will assume that she has a 40% probability of gaining the votes from the remaining countries. Hence, the votes she would receive (weighted by their respective probabilities) come to 59.60% (or 118.97% of the necessary majority). However, it will be imperative to adjust the probabilities as new information is released and to follow the remaining countries that have exclusive representation on the board of directors: Russia, Japan and Saudi Arabia. Possible Alternatives: As of now the only hint towards a possible rival is the rumour suggesting that Tidjane Thiam might be a likely competitor. However, I find it to be unsubstantial. TT took over as CEO of Credit Suisse less than one year ago (01/07/2015) and in addition has denied that he is in the running, saying: "I think it's public that I'm a fan, I've been on the record, and really I've only had one career strategy always, is to try to do my current job well." He continued: "I'm very focused on Credit Suisse and on delivering what I am committed to delivering at Credit Suisse," saying "I have a big job to do, and I am doing to the best of my ability." (12) However, he could very well be a plausible candidate for the term after this. Coming to the question of whether, should CL be replaced, her successor will be European or not: As she is currently heavily favoured to be re-elected, this question is only relevant should CL drop out of the race (for example due to the legal case in France against her), should she lose momentum or should a stronger candidate emerge that gains support from countries currently backing her. To me the most likely case seems to be her withdrawing from the race (55%) followed by her losing momentum (40%). In this case, the countries backing her would need to look for a new candidate. Of these countries, roughly half are European, so I would put the probability of her successor being European at 50% (with American / African candidates being the most likely alternatives). The same goes for the emergence of a new candidate that would get the backing from her current supporters (5%). Probability of her successor being European = 50%. So in aggregate, this comes to a 50% probability of her successor being non-European. Notice: This is only an initial assessment, which needs to be updated after other candidates have been announced. However, unless a nomination is made publicly, IMF treats it the list of candidates as confidential and will only publish names after narrowing candidates down to a shortlist consisting of three candidates. (13) Assessment of probability: Based on the above analysis, I find a second term for CL as MD of the IMF (where would we be without acronyms) to be very likely. As noted above, with the currently assigned probabilities she has 59.60% of votes or 118.97% of the necessary majority. My detailed calculation table can be found here: www.nico-enders.com/forecasting/imfcl This leads me to start with an 80% probability of her being elected, while weighting the mentioned risk factors, that could lead to the converse scenario, at 20%. Of these 20% the probability of her successor being European is 50% i.e. 10% in absolute terms. Risks: Upside:
Strong support from emerging economies
Additional support from countries with significant vote share Downside:
CL opts out of race – possible return to French politics (1)
US does not support candidacy
Countries withdraw support
Drop in probability of votes from supporting groups 
Strong alternative emerges Wildcards:
Russia, Japan, Saudi-Arabia

I didn't include all the rosy bits from the beginning -- just the first two paragraphs and then where Bremmer addresses why he thinks she should stay. Jan 19: "The IMF Needs More Lagarde" --> http://www.project-syndicate.org/commentary/imf-lagarde-strong-leadership-by-ian-bremmer-2016-01 Christine Lagarde has said she is open to serving another five-year term as Managing Director of the International Monetary Fund. She should get it. The IMF has never had better leadership, and its board of directors should give her the chance to finish the work she has begun. When Lagarde took the helm in July 2011, she inherited an institution in crisis. The global financial meltdown in 2008 and its economic aftershocks had discredited Western-led multilateral lenders and the free-market “Washington Consensus.” Lagarde’s leadership has helped to restore the Fund’s reputation.
[...]
Critics will say that it’s time for an IMF head who represents the developing world. Lagarde is, after all, the 11th consecutive European to hold the post, a privilege that has become hard to justify in today’s world. Others will say that the failure to recognize the full effects of IMF-endorsed austerity on Greek citizens proves that she is out of touch with ordinary people. Still others will argue that the charges she faces in connection with a financial scandal in France will distract her from IMF business. After the ugly scandal surrounding Dominique Strauss-Kahn, her predecessor at the Fund, the Fund, critics will insist, can’t afford such a distraction. Let’s take these objections one at a time. The IMF (and the World Bank) should welcome leadership from beyond Europe and the United States. But the purpose of ending this Western privilege is to make the leadership selection process one that is based on merit, not political considerations. Lagarde is the best candidate for the job, and emerging powers like the BRIC countries (Brazil, Russia, India, and China) have not united behind an alternative. The leadership of a European managing director probably facilitated the IMF’s decision late last year to add China’s renminbi to the basket of currencies underpinning its Special Drawing Rights. In addition, Lagarde displayed impressive political dexterity in finally persuading Republicans and Democrats in the US Congress to pass governance reforms that not only bolster the IMF’s firepower to fight financial crises, but also more accurately reflect changing global economic dynamics. The BRIC countries, for example, are now among the IMF’s top ten shareholders. On Greece, Lagarde made some characteristically blunt – some would say clumsy –comments last year. But she is not near the top of the list of those responsible for the economic pain endured by Greeks, and her tenure at the IMF makes abundantly clear that no managing director in history has done more to lead the Fund in efforts to alleviate the suffering of people in crisis. Finally, the French charges against Lagarde were filed over the objection of the country’s prosecutor-general, and her involvement in the case appears tangential at best. The world badly needs a leader dedicated to making the world a safer and more prosperous place. Lagarde has shown that she is such a leader, committed to making the IMF fit for the twenty-first century. She deserves the chance to finish what she started.

"But economists like Batista have another criticism of Lagarde’s directorship—and that criticism speaks directly to who she is rather than what she has done. “She is the 11th European in a row to run the IMF—it is an outdated position to reserve the managing directorship for a European,” Batista says. “If the IMF wants to be a 21st-century institution, it needs to have a truly merit-based system without this geographical preference. "Lagarde has also involved the IMF in humanitarian crises in ways that are new to the institution. " . . .  When the Ebola epidemic began in West Africa in 2014,. . . There are two factors suggesting Lagarde might not return as Managing Director. First, David Lipton, First Deputy Director, stated that the next Managing Director would likely come from outside Europe. However, this prediction was conditioned upon Lagarde stepping down - which she has not indicated she will do. Second, Lagarde is involved in a political dust-up in France that could make her winning re-election less likely. However, most reports on the subject suggest that the suit will not likely be a factor in her selection. Other factors suggest Lagarde is well positioned for a second term: adding the yuan to the SDR has likely reduced the likelihood of a challenge from the BRIC countries and, of course, Lagarde seems to want to pursue a second term. Of the previous ten managing directors, four served more than one term so serving multiple terms is not unprecedented. It should be more likely than not that Lagarde returns in her position. If she doesn't, Lipton's comment suggests a non-European Managing Director is more likely than a European Managing Director.

Despite facing charges in France, Christine Lagarde is expected to emerge unscathed. Either way, it is unlikely that a court ruling will be made prior to July 2016, thus increasing the likelihood that the IMF will continue to stand by Lagarde, especially at a time where there is significant global uncertainty fuelled by a slowdown in China, as well as the threat of Grexit looming in the shadows. The real question will be whether Lagarde decides to contest the French presidential elections in 2017, which may result in her resignation from the IMF at the end of her term. Either way, a European is most likely to head the IMF, when considering the disproportionate voting rights of European states as well as the United States. The BRIC nations have become highly vocal against the tradition of appointing a European to head the IMF, but unless there is a change to the voting structure, it is unlikely to make a difference.

AS OF THE 18TH OF DEC A French judicial commission has ordered International Monetary Fund chief Christine Lagarde to stand trial for alleged negligence over a decision she made as finance minister of France. Ms Lagarde is charged with negligence for her role settling a long-running legal dispute known as “ L’Affaire Tapie” between French entrepreneur and former politician Bernard Tapie and the state. As finance minister, Ms Lagarde decided to refer the dispute to an arbitration panel in 2007 that ultimately awarded Mr Tapie more than €400 million ($607m) in compensation. This month a court ordered Mr Tapie to reimburse the sum. The ruling by the judicial commission of France’s Cour de Justice de la République--a court that decides on alleged wrongdoings by government ministers while in office--came as a surprise Thursday because prosecutors had recommended in September the investigation of Ms. Lagarde be dropped.

When I first heard the news I thought, "Oh no. Here we go again. She's gone." But, when I read the following line, I changed my mind: "The court that would try Lagarde is a specialized one that deals with ministers accused of crimes related to their positions, and there aren’t a lot of precedents,"
http://washpost.bloomberg.com/Story?docId=1376-NZIS4B6K50XV01-14SMSJOUHVLI0QMTSKNK156MEQ Courts that try ministers for abuse of position has got to be the scariest concept around for any politician. No doubt they would be interested in circumscribing such a court. Further, a "negligence" charge is so very hard to prove because there is, I would expect, an automatic presumption that the minister is doing their duty. Something similar to the corporate "business judgement rule." So, here's a case that can be used to actually set precedent favorable to ministers in the future. The outcome, I expect, will be similar to that of how the U.S. Supreme court decided the "honest services fraud" cases on the positive side (requiring identification of a specific quid-pro-quo  kickback or bribe). Here, on the negligence side, they will probably require identification of a failure to perform a specific duty (rather than a more expansive "violation of principle" approach). The problem, of course, is that many wrongs are actually a complex of acts, each of which may be disassociated in time and type. (There was no crude cash payment [bribe] to perform ministerial act X today, but six months later the minister just happens to come across an excellent investment idea for a resort project in Montenegro. or earns appointment to a prestigious international banking body.]

Christine Lagarde has had a well-regarded term as managing director of the IMF, especially compared to her resigned-in-disgrace predecessor.  Incumbency is a powerful factor in this matter, both in her ability to keep the office and the lack of interest by voters in changing (being the first woman to head the IMF also leans in her favor. There is little to indicate that she doesn't want to keep the job.  However, were she not to, there would be pressure to appoint a non-European, given the EU's economic travails (and there would likely be heavy pressure not to appoint a German, and yet further amplify that country's power).  Note that "Some from outside Europe" doesn't mean direct from the developing world or what-have-you - Britain's new central bank head, a Canadian, would quality.

Largely following the crowd on this one. Couple of factors at play: (1) Lagarde seems to be leaning towards a second term (or, at the very least, not ruling one out). 
(2) Her term has generally been portrayed as successful (and scandal free), so there's no clear impetus to get rid of her. 
(3) The director of the IMF is traditionally a European (even though there is always chat about changing this) and Lagarde fits the bill.

A second term is likely in the books for Lagarde.  If this is not the case, there are a number of strong European candidates who would gladly take her place -- but I find it more likely that a candidate from outside Europe, particularly from Asia, would get the nod.

Barring a scandal, there doesn't seem any impetus to replace Lagarde. And she has implied that she would like a second term. Even European directors in the IMF have expressed a desire to consider candidates from the developing world in the near future. So, when Lagarde goes, non-European candidates will have more support than Mexican central banker Agustin Carstens was able to get last time.

FT article Oct 8, 2015 -- http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/a315b364-6de9-11e5-8171-ba1968cf791a.html#axzz3sROKRuPb Reuters article Oct 8, 2015-- http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/10/08/us-imf-lagarde-idUSKCN0S22OR20151008 The Reuters article has info of when she first made mention of this in October. The FT article goes a bit deeper and talks about how Lagarde could make the jump back to French politics. Given the events in Paris, I suspect that the "right-wing" of France won't be making a resurgence as support will (likely) coalesce around the current President (unless it's spun very well by the Right). Past MDs of the IMF -- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund#Managing_Director In looking at this list, I was surprised just how many past IMF MDs are French. Five (!) out of the 11 (or 12, if you count the interim). Of those 11 MDs, four had more than one term. The last to do so was 1987 through 2000 (Camdessus -- from France). This data point could be used to argue that there's going to only be one term for Lagarde or that it's been some time since there was a person with two terms. Interesting note, of the four that had more than one term, three (!) of them were French. Lastly -- http://www.ndtv.com/world-news/will-christine-lagarde-face-brics-challenge-as-imf-term-nears-end-1241508 -- "Will Christine Lagarde Face BRICS Challenge as IMF Term Nears End?" Nov 8, 2015 EXCERPT: As International Monetary Fund chief Christine Lagarde's mandate enters the final stretch, emerging-market powers seem hesitant about teaming up to try to wrest the job away from Europeans. The IMF managing director has said she is "open" to seeking another term when her time is up in July 2016, while the so-called BRICS -- Brazil, Russia, India, China and South Africa -- seem divided about a power bid. (...) In 2011, the BRICS were unable to agree on a single candidate who would convey undeniable symbolic clout, leaving Mexico's Agustin Carstens to pursue a losing battle against Lagarde. It is an open question whether that would be different today. (...) Cracks have appeared within the 188-nation IMF itself. In July, the institution's number-two official, David Lipton, told the BBC that it was "much more likely the next time around than it has ever been" that the next IMF chief will be a non-European. (...) The prospect of a common BRICS candidate, however, faces a number of obstacles, according to experts interviewed by AFP. The choice of a candidate, for starters. A former IMF chief economist who currently heads India's central bank, Raghuram Rajan, has the ideal profile but he himself has torpedoed speculation. (...) Beyond the question of candidates, it would be tough to challenge Lagarde if she seeks another term because she has strong backing among the institution's members, including the emerging-market economies. "Ms Lagarde has broad support among the IMF's membership," said economist Eswar Prasad, former head of the IMF's China division. "She has taken a number of steps to make the IMF more sensitive to emerging markets' concerns and sought to increase their representation at senior levels of the IMF's management and staff." According to Shi Yinhong, a professor at Renmin University of China, the battle seems to have a foregone conclusion because of the composition of the IMF executive board, which names the managing director and which remains dominated by Europeans and Americans. "Given Western countries' funding, their share of voting rights and their ability in and experience of managing international financial organizations, I believe the managing director candidate will still come from a developed country," he said. \\\ COMMENT: This last article squares it for me. Until Lagarde says she's "out," I think she's the leading candidate.
